P.FONT: mid 90s techno-ish sounds, reminds me of outdoor raves, a level of intensity which would increase with continued repitition.
happy, fun, but, as with much music of that nature, a distinct possibility that it could become fairly tacky after a while. but, initially, quite inviting.

the conflicting rhythms would be the hardest thing to transition, so i think pulling as much rhythmical information out of the source material would be necessary. the sounds themselves seem fairly compatible, i could imagine an almost hip=hop style crossfade back and forth between the sounds (minus the rhytmic detail) could be effective.

well, i think it's a matter of pulling out the sounds which are producing the swing in the source material, most noticably the hi-hat sound and probably the bass, then doing likewise to the target sound (where, again, the hats seem to produce most of the 'straightness'), then hard crossfading back and forth between the two a few times, then introducing the full target sounds.

the rhythm is the biggest factor, though since only a limited number of sounds produce the specific rhythms in each, simply removing those would still leave quite a lot of sound there to play between the two.
i didn't really like it much personally. i think a much more cut and paste response is needed to get the rhythms to work - the blend seems very forced.
i think a lot. a lack of perceived smoothness made me feel that it was too forced and was done because it had to be done, not because it actually should be done.
i think trying to make it smooth is the wrong approach, so that attempt at smoothness immediately provoked an unfavourable response.
i can hear the first sound from the target.
cowbell sound - but source material is still in full swing, so there doesn't feel like the space is yet there for its introduction.
messy clash of pitch.
the targets pitched sounds begin to fade in, in a different key to source.
bass sounds change nicely.
the bass sound from the source remains as the last significant sound and actually fits rhythmically well, making the transition to the target bass sounds fairly nice.
new rhythm kicks in.
the first point at which the target rhythm takes the dominant role, and my head can start to make sense of why the transition sounds so awkward.

yes, i think it would be. my experience in doing such things tells me that the average person doesn't listen for those details, especially when their attention is distracted by something else (images, conversation etc etc).

i would not try to make the transition between rhythms gradual and smooth, because they just can't be. i would make a series of hard cuts between the two. i think people would notice a transition more this way, but not feel the awkwardness of the transition as presented above. this would have the effect of them feeling change, but not feeling it forced upon them so much.
pull specific sounds from each piece with to make the series of hard cuts. it would just make it a bit more subtle, while still maintaining the cut and paste aesthetic.
a much better approach, i feel. the rhythm of the source completely disappears before the new rhythm is introduced, yet little melodic and punctuating sounds from the two appear intermingled.
i think it was a less smooth transition, than the first, but much better because of this.
yes, it allowed each piece of music to be itself. they weren't being forced to become one piece, but the common things were brought out and used effectively.
noticing something changing and therefore giving me an expectation.
dsp (?) deterioration of the high pitched sounds in the source material make it feel like the source sound is coming to an end, preparing me for a change
i can hear what might be coming up.
first recognisable sound from target - organ stab. fits both in terms of rhythm and pitch.
rhythm reduced to tempo only
all rhythm removed and only tempo keeping kick left, allowing a new rhythm in different tempo to be introduced at...
new rhythm
having been given the space for the old rhythm to disappear, the new one now sounds unforced, as it is still at the same tempo.
yes, because it sounds natural, doesn't jar anywhere.

not much, maybe one or two minor sounds from the source material remaining a bit longer. as the target gets to come in over the source, having the source still remaining over the target (but only small sounds) would link the two pieces more thoroughly.
generic electronic music produced to try to emulate classic acoustic styles and feels on a budget. don't really like it.
much more positive. electronic sounds allowed to be electronic. sounds like a small break before a very beefy rhythm kicks in.
it sounds like two very distinct moods in some sort of cheap crime film, so i'd want the two to be able to contrast with each other clearly.
i would want the first piece to have a resolving note which lingers, then thetarget piece to have an intro (eg. roll etc.) and then kick in to completely change the mood.
none, really, as long as i could get the last beat of the source material to ring out.
i quite enjoyed it. it was hard to tell which sounds were coming from which piece, they combined well without ever sounding forced.
surprisingly good. i was impressed at how smooth the two pieces, which i had orginally thought quite different, were able to transition.
i think the smooth transitions worked well in this case.
oh no - double time!
first hints of delayed sounds which double the rhythm of the source to match it to target.
ok - it's not just hitting a cliche double time!
the point at which i was expecting the double time to just kick in, but it doesn't. pleasantly surprising me.
i like that bass sound.
the squelchy bass sound of the target begins to dominate. it can fit either rhythm so doesn't jar with either, but transitions well.
not quite even yet.
again, i was expecting the target rhythm to kick in, but it doesn't (thankfully), allowing the old rhythm time to leave before the new one takes over.
yes. because it's unobtrusive yet successful.
i would fade the source material out less and make it's disappearance a little more sudden at around the 20 second mark.

o.k. but not brilliant, the source and target loops were out of sequence with each other - i.e. if you imagine each loop as having groups of four bars, logically bar one of the source would overlap with bar one of the target - this didn't happen, throwing my sense of keeping in place, and making me notice the changeover in a negative manner.
it was good for a while, until my head which naturally counts the groups of bars in pieces of music, couldn't keep the two together, because they weren't.
no - it felt like a mistake that the creator failed to recognise and so didn't fix.
nice introduction of target.
first pieces of target sounds - some high pitched blips - subtle and successful.
that's the cliche i was expecting last time.
double time kicks in from target - what a cliche.
this isn't matching up.
first able to discern that the two structures are out of sync (see notes on last page)
source is gone.
source seems to perceptably disappear.
probably. does the average listener listen for subleties?
move the target back half a bar to fix the sync problems. it won't sound odd then.
not bad apart from the g.m. guitar simulation. why not just get a guitarist? fairly sunny.
much darker - and hinting at a full on assault of driving darkness which may just be up there past the next drum roll.
the rhythms fit fairly well, so i would want to concentrate on turning the lightness into darkness in terms of the sounds.
drop the guitar as early as possible (because it sucks anyway) and start bringing in the darker blips. i think a fairly smooth transition can be made between the two.
the rhythms are quite close, the sounds are also - there's some synths in the source which could sound quite dark in a different context.
the guitar just really annoys me and kills what would otherwise be a reasonable transition here. the parts seem to crossfade fairly distincyly without too much of combining elements.
it tried to be smooth, but failed because one sound was too dominant (guitar) and faded without making an impact disappearance.
no. the fade of the guitar was not good.
target appearance.
the first hints of the darker subsynth sounds from the target material.
ugly fade.
guitar, which has totally dominated, fades mid-riff, but not completely.
that's it?
target is fully kicked in, and that's it, no spectacular change etc.
probably - if you can put up with hearing the guitar, then you can probably overlook the heavy handed fade.
kill the guitar at the end of the riff, at 0:4. then let the rest of this fade run its course.
a much stronger go, though the rhythms change more perceptably than i had expected. the crossover in terms of sounds from each is good.
i think it was smooth in a positive way, though holding the target rhythm back a couple more bars may have made it even smoother.
i think they were fairly positively smooth.
new sounds
target blips begin.
yayyyy!!!!!
that bloody guitar is just gone! about time. and it happens at the end of a riff, a logical and impactful place, with a successful cut, not a bland fade
nice shifts
the synth wash sounds seem to transition really well, darkening the whole piece.
not just yet!
target rhythm kicks in - a little early.
yes, because it's a logical and unobtrusive transition.
i would just hold the main rhythm of the target off for another four bars, to give a little more space to both pieces.
happy, nice 303 sounds, reminds me a little of classic acid house.
a straighter version of the last piece - 4 on the floor kicks instead of the syncopation, but otherwise very similar.
not too much to be done - the similarities between the two are fairly strong.
a straight cut from one to the other could almost work - perhaps a roll of some sort to build up to the change from syncopation to a straight drive would help.
the similarities in sounds, style etc of the two make it a fairly simple task.
i don't like this transition much - why try to crossfade them??!!!

it tries for a smooth transition which completely kills it. the two pieces could be different sections from one piece of music, just cut between them - the attempt at smoothness does not work at all for me.
the smoothness was incredibly deficient. it kills the stregths of the two pieces and the pitch issues are very obvious.
is that out of tune?
new melody comes in, without the source melody completely disappearing - the two are in different keys and cause pitch problems.
straightens ups the beat
target kick kicks (!) in, straighteneing the groove right up, without anything to help anticipate this. makes it sound a bit awkward.
no more syncopation
all rhythmic elements of the source are now gone, so the rhythm is now straight up and down.
probably - it is subtle enough to get away with, again especially if there's other distractions.
not try to crossfade at all - just make a straight cut as if it was a different piece of the same track - a key change or whatever - but add a roll beforehand to build anticipation of this shift.
a better transition but, again, too much focus on blending the two bits. they already have enough in common - don't worry about blending - just cut!!!
i don't like smoothness for this transition, so it has a large negative effect.
again, no - the smooth changes were deficient and distract from the strengths of both pieces.
rhythm pulling back
the rhythms of the source material are pulling back to make way for the new rhythm.
straighten up
target kick pattern comes in, replacing the syncopation with drive.
new key/melody
303 bass sound changes melody, key and rhythm.
all target
reamining pieces of source rhythm disappear.
yes, it is quite seemless.
again, i would stop worrying about segueing and just cut with an anticipatory roll.

piano lessons fro age 9-14. self taught guitar, bass, drums, mandolin etc. played in regular bands for about 10 years. began producing purely electronic music about 6 or 7 years ago after blaending it with guitar pop for a few years before that. now bouncing all over the place between different electronic and traditional styles. wide wide range of musical tastes from jugband and crossraod blues to rockabilly to 60s garage and pop to electronica in all its forms and crossovers with indi pop.
1hr 45mins
